question: [File: aptos-core/aptos-move/aptos-native-interface/src/builder.rs] [Function: make_native()] [Gas bypass] Can a malicious native function manipulate the legacy_gas_used field in SafeNativeContext to undercharge gas, allowing attackers to execute expensive operations for free and causing validator resource exhaustion? (Critical)

[File: aptos-core/aptos-move/aptos-native-interface/src/builder.rs] [Function: make_native()] [Gas manipulation] In the closure at lines 98-167, if a native function sets context.legacy_gas_used to 0 before returning, can it bypass gas charging entirely while the assertion at line 123 passes due to has_direct_gas_meter_access_in_native_context() returning true? (Critical)

[File: aptos-core/aptos-move/aptos-native-interface/src/builder.rs] [Function: make_native()] [Integer overflow] Can the legacy_gas_used accumulator overflow when summing gas costs across multiple native function calls, wrapping to a small value and allowing transactions to execute with insufficient gas payment? (High)

[File: aptos-core/aptos-move/aptos-native-interface/src/builder.rs] [Function: make_native()] [Gas undercharge] When returning NativeResult::ok(context.legacy_gas_used, ret_vals) at line 132, if legacy_gas_used is incorrectly tracked due to a bug in the native function, can this allow operations to complete with undercharged gas, breaking gas economics? (High)

[File: aptos-core/aptos-move/aptos-native-interface/src/builder.rs] [Function: make_native()] [Double charging] Can the combination of legacy_gas_used and direct gas meter access cause double gas charging in edge cases, leading to unfair gas costs and potential transaction failures? (Medium)

[File: aptos-core/aptos-move/aptos-native-interface/src/builder.rs] [Function: make_native()] [Gas hook bypass] If the gas_hook callback at line 114 is not invoked or fails silently, can gas accounting become inconsistent between validators, causing state divergence and consensus failures? (Critical)

[File: aptos-core/aptos-move/aptos-native-interface/src/builder.rs] [Function: make_native()] [Feature version bypass] Can an attacker exploit the gas_feature_version field (line 106) to use outdated gas parameters from a previous version, allowing them to execute operations with lower gas costs than intended? (High)

[File: aptos-core/aptos-move/aptos-native-interface/src/builder.rs] [Function: with_incremental_gas_charging()] [State corruption] When temporarily modifying enable_incremental_gas_charging (lines 71-74), if action() panics before restoration at line 74, can this leave the builder in an inconsistent state affecting subsequent native function creation? (Medium)

[File: aptos-core/aptos-move/aptos-native-interface/src/builder.rs] [Function: make_native()] [Out of gas bypass] At line 138-140, when LegacyOutOfGas is detected, the assertion checks !has_direct_gas_meter_access_in_native_context(). Can a malicious native function manipulate context state to pass this assertion while actually having direct gas meter access, bypassing out-of-gas checks? (Critical)

[File: aptos-core/aptos-move/aptos-native-interface/src/builder.rs] [Function: make_native()] [Gas charging on error] When an error occurs and NativeResult::err(context.legacy_gas_used, abort_code) is returned at line 135, can a malicious native function deliberately abort with minimal gas charged to avoid paying for expensive failed operations? (High)

[File: aptos-core/aptos-move/aptos-native-interface/src/builder.rs] [Function: make_native()] [Memory undercharge] Can a malicious native function manipulate legacy_heap_memory_usage (line 121) to report less memory usage than actually consumed, bypassing memory limits and causing node memory exhaustion? (Critical)

[File: aptos-core/aptos-move/aptos-native-interface/src/builder.rs] [Function: make_native()] [Assertion bypass] The assertion at line 124 checks legacy_heap_memory_usage == 0 when direct gas meter access is available. Can a native function with direct access intentionally set non-zero memory usage to trigger this assertion and cause validator panics? (High)

[File: aptos-core/aptos-move/aptos-native-interface/src/builder.rs] [Function: make_native()] [Memory tracking bypass] After extracting legacy_heap_memory_usage at line 121, the use_heap_memory_in_native_context() call at line 129 charges memory. Can this be bypassed if the gas meter is in a corrupted state, allowing unlimited memory consumption? (High)

[File: aptos-core/aptos-move/aptos-native-interface/src/builder.rs] [Function: make_native()] [Integer overflow] Can legacy_heap_memory_usage overflow when a native function allocates excessive memory, wrapping to a small value and bypassing memory limits? (High)

[File: aptos-core/aptos-move/aptos-native-interface/src/builder.rs] [Function: make_native()] [Memory DoS] If use_heap_memory_in_native_context() at line 129 fails but the error is not properly propagated, can this allow unbounded memory growth across multiple transactions, causing validator node crashes? (High)

[File: aptos-core/aptos-move/aptos-native-interface/src/builder.rs] [Function: make_native()] [Error type confusion] At lines 133-165, different SafeNativeError variants are handled differently. Can an attacker craft inputs causing incorrect error type classification, leading to wrong gas charging or improper error propagation? (High)

[File: aptos-core/aptos-move/aptos-native-interface/src/builder.rs] [Function: make_native()] [Invariant violation handling] When InvariantViolation error occurs at line 151, it directly returns Err(err) without charging gas. Can malicious native functions deliberately trigger invariant violations to avoid gas payment for expensive operations? (High)

[File: aptos-core/aptos-move/aptos-native-interface/src/builder.rs] [Function: make_native()] [LimitExceeded confusion] The LimitExceeded error has two variants (lines 137-148): LegacyOutOfGas and LimitExceeded. Can edge cases in native functions cause incorrect variant selection, leading to different gas charging behavior across validators? (Critical)

[File: aptos-core/aptos-move/aptos-native-interface/src/builder.rs] [Function: make_native()] [Assertion panic] At line 146, assert!(context.has_direct_gas_meter_access_in_native_context()) is called when LimitExceeded error occurs. Can a malicious native function trigger this with incorrect context state to cause validator panics and liveness failures? (Critical)

[File: aptos-core/aptos-move/aptos-native-interface/src/builder.rs] [Function: make_native()] [Error unpack vulnerability] At line 147, err.unpack() is called which could potentially panic or have undefined behavior. Can this be exploited to cause validator crashes or state corruption? (High)

[File: aptos-core/aptos-move/aptos-native-interface/src/builder.rs] [Function: make_native()] [Function dispatch bypass] When FunctionDispatch error occurs (lines 152-163), it returns NativeResult::CallFunction with the provided module_name, func_name, ty_args, and args. Can a malicious native function use this to call arbitrary functions bypassing normal access controls? (Critical)

[File: aptos-core/aptos-move/aptos-native-interface/src/builder.rs] [Function: make_native()] [Module injection] At line 164, LoadModule error allows loading arbitrary modules by name. Can this be exploited to load malicious modules or bypass module verification, potentially executing unauthorized code? (Critical)

[File: aptos-core/aptos-move/aptos-native-interface/src/builder.rs] [Function: make_native()] [Type argument injection] In the FunctionDispatch path (line 155), ty_args are passed through without validation. Can an attacker inject malicious type arguments to bypass type safety checks or cause type confusion vulnerabilities? (High)

[File: aptos-core/aptos-move/aptos-native-interface/src/builder.rs] [Function: make_native()] [Argument injection] At line 156, args from the native function are directly passed to the dispatched function. Can this bypass argument validation, allowing malformed or malicious values to be passed to privileged functions? (High)

[File: aptos-core/aptos-move/aptos-native-interface/src/builder.rs] [Function: make_native()] [Cross-module call exploit] The FunctionDispatch mechanism allows calling functions in different modules (line 153-154). Can this be used to create call chains that bypass security checks or access restricted functionality? (High)
